title: US airlines: loyalty schemes are revenue gold
text:
Holidaymakers are a loyal bunch. Crowds of luggage-toting Americans have packed airports this summer despite pricier flights and hotels. More than 2mn people have passed through US airport screenings every day since early June. On some days, volumes have surpassed pre-pandemic levels, according to the Transport Security Administration.

One group reluctant to join in the fun is investors. Stock prices for the four biggest US airlines by revenues — Delta, American Airlines, United and Southwest — have dropped between a fifth and a third since late April despite the travel boom.

Some of this bearishness is justified. Staff shortages have forced airlines to cancel thousands of flights. Jet fuel costs have doubled in the past year. A recession could hurt travel demand.

Even so, airlines deserve more loyalty. Many have a lucrative side business that provides a steady stream of revenue in their frequent flyer programmes. Airlines successfully used them as collateral to raise millions of dollars during the pandemic.

Delta's partnership with American Express — which makes up the bulk of its SkyMiles loyalty programme — should bring in more than $5bn in revenue this year. That's equal to about 11 per cent of Delta's estimated group total. Delta believes income from Amex could top $7bn by 2024.

Profits from the card deal — in which Amex buys miles from Delta to give as rewards to its own customers — also make a difference. Past filings reveal that Delta's SkyMiles programme generated $2.5bn in net income in 2019 — more than half of group net income that year. Expect that to climb in the next two years.

At United, the $1.57bn in net profit generated by its MileagePlus programme in 2019 was a similar proportion of total net profit. The unit's 34 per cent ebitda margin trumps the airline's 10 per cent total.

As companies attempt to get into the consumer credit card business, demand for air miles peddled by airlines should continue to take flight.
